tit.e: Ashigaru taisho (general in command of a troop of foot soldiers)
Ashigaru taisho (general in command of a troop of foot soldiers)
Ashigaru taisho (general in command of a troop of foot soldiers)

sen.j: 足軽大将（あしがるたいしょう）とは、日本の戦国時代_(日本)に、戦国大名のもとで足軽隊を率いた部将及びその職のことをいう。
sen.e: Ashigaru taisho was a commanding officer or its post, who led Ashigaru troops (a troop of foot soldiers) under the Warring lords in the Japanese Warring States period.
An Ashigaru taisho was a commanding officer who lead Ashigaru troops (foot soldiers) under a daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) during Japan's Sengoku Period (period of warring states).
sen.cmt: Fixed according to the word list: Warring lords→daimyo (Japanese territorial lord; Japanese Warring States→Sengoku Period (period of warring states); fixed grammar
sen.e: An Ashigaru taisho was a commanding officer who lead Ashigaru troops (foot soldiers) under a daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) during Japan's Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

sen.j: 足軽頭（あしがるがしら）ともいう。
sen.e: This was also called Ashigarugashira.
They were also called Ashigarugashira.
They were also called Ashigarugashira.

sen.j: また、江戸時代には物頭（ものがしら）とも称された。
sen.e: In the Edo period, it was called Monogashira as well.
During the Edo Period, they were also referred to as Monogashira.
During the Edo period, they were also referred to as Monogashira.

sen.j: 室町時代まで足軽は工兵的な役割であった。
sen.e: Until the Muromachi period, Ashigaru had served rather as a military engineer.
Until the Muromachi Period, Ashigaru had served as a type of military engineer.
sen.cmt: "rather" does not feel natural here so I changed it to "type" as a translation of "-的"
sen.e: Until the Muromachi period, Ashigaru had served as a type of military engineer.

sen.j: 応仁の乱以降、合戦における将兵の軽装化が進み、足軽が主力のひとつとして活躍するようになった。
sen.e: After the Onin War, as light-armored soldiers were required in battles, Ashigaru was used as a main battle force.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: After the Onin War, as officers and soldiers in battles wore only light armor, Ashigaru came to have an active role as a main battle force.
After the Onin War, as officers and soldiers in battles wore only light armor, Ashigaru came to have an active role as a main battle force.

sen.j: 戦国時代を迎える頃には合戦の集団戦化が本格化・大規模化し機動性ある足軽の役割は益々重くなっていった。
sen.e: At the time of the Warring States period, as battles became more organized and complexed on a large scale, the role of Ashigaru acquired greater importance due to its movability.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: During the Sengoku Period, battles became more organzied and complex on a large scale and the role of Ashigaru became increasingly important due to their mobility.
sen.cmt: Warring States period→Sengoku Period; fixed grammar
sen.e: During the Sengoku Period, battles became more organized and complex on a large scale and the role of Ashigaru became increasingly important due to their mobility.

sen.j: 特に足軽は訓練された槍・弓 (武器)・鉄砲の足軽隊が組織され主力軍として活躍するようになりった。
sen.e: Especially, Ashigaru troops, in which foot soldiers were trained to handle spears, bows, and guns (arms), were established and served as main-force units.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Ashigaru troops in particular, who were trained with spears, bows and guns, were organized and became active as a main fighting force.
Ashigaru troops in particular, who were trained with spears, bows and guns, were organized and became active as a main fighting force.

sen.j: 戦国大名の家臣である者が足軽大将に任じられ、足軽隊を率いて活躍するようになった。
sen.e: Retainers of the Warring lords, who were appointed to Ashigaru taisho, did remarkable services by leading Ashigaru troops; Ashigaru taisho was ranked immediately below Sodaisho (supreme commander) of feudal lords and Samurai daisho (commander of warriors), leading soldiers including his immediate subordinates, Ashigaru kogashira or Ashigaru kumigashira (foot soldier captains).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Retainers of daimyo who were appointed to the position of Ashigaru taisho made great achievements leading Ashigaru troops. They were ranked immediately below the Sodaisho (commander in chief) and Samurai daisho (commander of warriors) and lead soldiers including Ashigaru kogashira (also called Ashigaru kumigashira) (foot soldier captains) who were their own subordinates.
sen.cmt: I could not comfortably keep this as one sentence, so I made it into two; changed content in parenthesis pertaining to "Sodaisho" to correspond to the definition in the article; fixed grammar
sen.e: Retainers of daimyo who were appointed to the position of Ashigaru taisho made great achievements leading Ashigaru troops.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。さらに2文に分けました。

sen.j: 総大将たる大名、侍大将に次ぐ地位を有し、配下である足軽小頭（足軽組頭）をはじめとする兵を率いた。
sen.e: They were ranked immediately below the daimyo as Sodaisho (commander in chief) and Samurai daisho (commander of warriors) and lead soldiers including Ashigaru kogashira (also called Ashigaru kumigashira) (foot soldier captains) who were their own subordinates.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。さらに2文に分けました。

sen.j: このような活躍の中で、次第に足軽大将の地位も向上し、戦国時代後期における足軽大将の家禄は、おおよそ200石から500石程度で中級の武士として認められる存在になった。
sen.e: Under such circumustances, the position of Ashigaru taisho gradually rose; they were provided with an annual stipend of 200 to 500 koku in the late Warring States period, and regarded as the middle-class warriors.

Due to their achievements, the position of Ashigaru taisho gradually rose, and in the late Sengoku Period they were provided with an annual stipend of 200 to 500 koku, and regarded as the middle-class warriors.
sen.cmt: このような活躍の中で→due to their achievements; fixed "Warring States"→"Sengoku Period" per word list;
sen.e: Due to their achievements, the position of Ashigaru taisho gradually rose, and in the late Sengoku Period they were provided with an annual stipend of 200 to 500 koku, and regarded as the middle-class warriors.
